Title.En: CARE (Medical Connected Sensors and Virtual Reality)

Description.En:
Have you ever wanted to know more about how blood sugar and blood pressure is measured?  This micromodule focuses on digital health and uses innovative teaching  tools to focus on connected health devices, remote medical monitoring and the surveillance of human health at home or in a medical environment. It will enable a wide audience to discover the world of digital health, which is particularly interesting for students who will have a  link with healthcare in their future professional life, but also for everybody interested in health.

Students will work in multidisciplinary and intercultural teams to discover medical monitoring systems, the assembly of a virtual  reality object (electronic card), and the transmission and  analysis of medical data. Volunteers will be equipped with a blood sugar or pressure device to interpret their own data.  The students will choose in international teams  the sensor they would like to work on (blood sugar or blood pressure sensor).  They will produce 3D scans of the device and learn the basis of 3D modelling of an object. They will also disassemble their device in virtual reality.   The work can be done fully online, but a mobility week is proposed to allow international students to do practical work onsite at INSA Toulouse.

Title.En: Discuss digital health and analyse key concepts in telehealth

PrefLabel.En: complying with health and safety procedures
advise on healthcare users' informed consent
protect health and well-being while using digital technologies

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of this micromodule, you will be able to discuss the challenges of digital health and analyze the concepts of responsibility, informed consent, and information systems security.

Title.En: Describe the functioning, assemblage, and purpose of connected medical devices.

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of this micromodule, you will be able to describe the principle of connected health devices, conceive, assemble and dismantle a medical monitoring device in a virtual reality environment .

Title.En: Write and implement algorithims, and interpret data

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of this micromodule, you will be able to write and implement simple algorithms for processing medical sensor data and interpret the data obtained.

Title.En: Working in an intercultural and interdisciplinary team to present results in English

NoteLiteral.En: By the end of this micromodule, you will be able to integrate an interdisciplinary and international team and present the methodology used and the main results in a foreign language (English).

Title.En: CARE (Medical Connected Sensors and Virtual Reality)
CARE (Medical Connected Sensors and Virtual Reality)

LegalName.En: INSTITUT NATIONAL DES SCIENCES APPLIQUEES DE TOULOUSE (INSA TOULOUSE)

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
**This micro-module is 2 ECTS and 1 ECTS for the mobility week**  

**Programme (detailed content) :**

Weeks 1 – 2: synchronous and asynchronous work January 27th –February 7th, online work 6h,

- Understanding how a sensor works, with the example of a blood glucose level sensor and a blood pressure sensor showing the influence of diet on this level. Volunteers will be equipped with a glucose sensor to analyze the data transmitted.

- Discovery of interdisciplinary and multicultural work, creation of international groups

Weeks 3 and 5 - 12 : synchronous and asynchronous work February 10th- May 9th, online work approx. 3h/week, on site 1H/week and 2h/week for INSA students

- Work in multidisciplinary and international teams to design a 3D medical monitoring model for injection into a virtual reality device (a cave, a 27 m3 Virtual reality device). To do this:

- The students will choose a monitoring device and design a 3D model of the sensor starting with a 3D scan. They will describe their choice in a 100-word essay in English (the 3D model will then be transformed by INSA Toulouse specialists, possibly assisted by students with the necessary skills, in a virtual reality environment).

- The students will  disassemble the elements of the virtual sensor

- They will develop a simple monitoring and data analysis system for their device and interpret the data.

Optional : Week 4: Mobility week February 17th-February 21st , onsite synchronous, 15 h

- Interested international students will be welcomed in Toulouse in week 4 to work with the French members of their teams. They will visit the CNRS-LAAS (National Center for Scientific Research) and the CHU (Toulouse University Hospital) to see research and the application of monitoring devices. They can also experience the Virtual Reality installation at INSA.

Week 13: May 12th – May 16th Hybrid, synchronous 3h

- Presentations of the devices, the results and their analysis, as well as the methodology employed in English to the other students and a jury.

**Assessment :**

Several formative assessments will check the achievement of the learning objectives throughout the micromodule.

The final assessment is the presentation at the end of the micromodule.

**Learning activities :**

\* Discover and discuss the challenges of digital health

\* Work efficently in an interdisciplinary and international team

\* Describe the principle of connected objects in health and the specific sensors chosen

\* Model and use a sensor device for medical monitoring

\* Disassemble a medical monitoring device in a virtual reality environment

\* Simulate the transmission and processing of data from the monitoring system and interpret the data obtained

\* Write and implement simple algorithms for processing medical sensor data

\* Summarize the methodology used and the main results in a foreign language and present them to a jury.
Discover medical monitoring systems, the transmission and analysis of medical data, and disassemble a sensor using VR

This micromodule will focus on connected health devices, remote medical monitoring and in particular, human health monitoring at home or in a medical environment. Students will learn how to scan an object with a 3D scanner, disassemble medical sensors in virtual reality and work on transmission and analysis of medical data. They will learn how biomedical sensors and systems work, and how interstitial fluid will be “transformed” into a value in an app. Volunteers will be equipped with connected glucose sensors and though be able to work on their own data. This micromodule will enable a wide audience to discover digital health, which is particularly interesting for those who will have a link with the health field in their future professional life. Students will work in international and interdisciplinary groups. An international mobility to INSA Toulouse is also an optional element for this micromodule.

Interested students should apply by sending a CV, transcript of records, and a motivation letter at least one week before the deadline. They need not be currently studying a scientific subject, as they will work in interdisciplinary teams, but they should be interested in health, technology and digital devices.

Students should be prepared to work in international teams with mostly asynchronous, but also some synchronous, work.
